Award.AwardTitle: Math Pathways: A Longitudinal, Dyadic Study of Parent-Child Influence in Latino Families

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This study aims to improve educational practices by filling critical gaps in research on the impact of relationships on mathematics achievement for Latino students. The study has two main objectives: First, the PIs will use longitudinal data and advanced statistical approaches to understand factors that influence mathematics attitudes and achievement during the transition from elementary to middle school. Second, the PIs will apply the expectancy-value model to the prediction of mathematics behavior and performance. Surveys will be collected from 300 Latino mothers, students, and their math teachers near the end of 5th grade, at the beginning and end of 6th grade, and at the beginning of 7th grade.

The intellectual merit is its potential to advance understanding of how and why interest in mathematics develops or declines over time, and how parents and teachers respond to these changes. The work will address broader impacts and benefit society by contributing to the body of literature concerning Latino students in STEM and has the potential to influence both parental behaviors and teaching practices as they relate to underrepresented populations. A graduate student will be trained to develop and apply analytic tools for interdependent data to STEM education content, helping to address the critical shortage of quantitative methodologists. The findings will be disseminated to researchers, teachers, parent and teacher educators, and parents.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The belief that parents and teachers influence students’ academic attitudes and performance is widely held, but poorly documented in mathematics, particularly among Latino families, and we know little about the degree to which changes in parent and teacher attitudes are driven by child performance and attitudes. This study aimed to understand how relational processes enhance or undermine Latino/a students’ beliefs and performance in mathematics during the transition from elementary school into middle school. There were three main objectives: First, to recruit and retain over time 300 families from an underperforming and understudied group: Latinos in a poor, agricultural communities. Second, to use longitudinal data from mother-child-teacher triads, and advanced statistical approaches, to understand factors that influence mathematics attitudes and achievement during the transition from elementary to middle school. Third, to apply existing theories of motivation to understand how mathematics beliefs change over time.

 

The results contribute to knowledge about how relationships with mothers and teachers can be used to increase the math success of Latino/a students. Perceived math ability increased for students whose mothers were more involved in their schoolwork, and for who felt closer to their teachers. Teacher expectations also predicted changes in the students’ own expectations for success in math, but only among high-achieving students. Perceptions of math ability can serve as a protective factor against a common decline in math interest during the transition to middle school. In this study, while math interest declined overall, it declined less for students with more positive views of their math ability. The findings also suggest areas in which parents are more disconnected from their children’s math experience than they realize. For example, mothers perceive their children as having higher levels of math interest and self-concept than their children do, and the discrepancy is greater among mothers with lower English acculturation.   

 

The broader impacts of this study include information that can be used to enhance parent education and teacher training programs. Relevant results include how and why math interest and expectations for success change over time, and the role played by parents and teachers in these changes. They also include findings about how mothers’ beliefs shape their own behavior, as well as the beliefs and behaviors of their child, and the areas in which parent and child view diverge. These findings were shared directly with parents, teachers, and school administrators, and formed the basis for a grant proposal to apply the findings countywide. The project also resulted in a published manuscript on ethical and effective strategies for recruiting and retaining Latina mothers from low income communities in education research. And the results show the importance of collecting data from both parents and children, and of using analytic techniques designed for nonindependent data in order to specify who is influencing whom. The project trained several graduate students, which resulted in new scholars with the tools and content expertise to conduct interdependent data analysis focused on STEM education.
